review.title: On TimeML-Compliant Temporal Expression Extraction in Turkish
review.abstract: It is commonly acknowledged that temporal expression extractors are important components of larger natural language processing systems like information retrieval and question answering systems. Extraction and normalization of temporal expressions in Turkish has not been given attention so far except the extraction of some date and time expressions within the course of named entity recognition. As TimeML is the current standard of temporal expression and event annotation in natural language texts, in this paper, we present an analysis of temporal expressions in Turkish based on the related TimeML classification (i.e., date, time, duration, and set expressions). We have created a lexicon for Turkish temporal expressions and devised considerably wide-coverage patterns using the lexical classes as the building blocks. We believe that the proposed patterns, together with convenient normalization rules, can be readily used by prospective temporal expression extraction tools for Turkish.

metadata.title: On TimeML-Compliant Temporal Expression Extraction in Turkish

sections.text: ar Xiv: 150 9,00 963v 1 [cs.C L] 3S ep2 015Keywords: Turkish, temporal expression, TimeML, information extraction

sections.heading: 1. Introduction
sections.text: Therefore, several text analysis applications, such as event extractors (Ritter et al., 2012) and text-based video annotation systems (Ku ¿c, Ku ¿k and Yazıcı, 2011), include a temporal expression extractor as a submodule to identify, normalize and then use these expressions. Traditionally, temporal expressions such as some date and time expressions have been considered as designated entities and included within the scope of designated entity recognition systems (NER). For example, the Measure Understanding Conference (MUC) uses series of temporary expressions (Grishman and Sundheim, 1996) that have been conducted over several years to promote research in information extraction, some date and time expressions have been considered within the scope of the NIS task, and related guidelines recommend these expressions to be annotated with the TIMEX tag.

sections.heading: 2. Temporal Expressions in Turkish
sections.text: Before we introduce the lexical resources and patterns for temporal expressions in Turkish, we briefly summarize their two peculiarities in formal Turkish texts, which should also be taken into account in the development of the system.These written rules are provided below, following the corresponding language rules published by Tu ¼ rk Dil Kurumu ("Turkish Language Association") (TDK, 2015): • The signs within temporal expressions are all lowercase, except for the names of the months and days of the week, which have capitalized their initials.Example expressions are bugu ¨ n ("today"), yarından sonraki gu ¨ n ("the day after tomorrow"), Pazartesi sabahı ("Monday morning"), Mayın ikinci Pazar ¨ nu ¨ nu ¨ ("the second Sunday of the month), in which we refer to the time systems of the time systems of the time systems of the time systems of the time systems of the time systems of the time systems of the time systems of the time systems of the time systems of the time systems of the time systems of the time systems of the time systems of the time systems of the time systems of the time systems of the time systems of the time systems of the time systems of the time systems of the time systems of the time systems of the time systems of the time systems of the time systems of the time systems of the time systems of the time systems of the time systems of the time systems of the time systems of the time systems of the time systems of the time systems

sections.heading: 2.1. Turkish Lexicon for Temporal Expressions
sections.text: We have constructed the Turkish Dictionary of Temporal Expressions with the following lexical classes: Class names are given in brackets and are used in the ultimate extraction patterns such as the building blocks. 1. The list of cardinal numbers from 1 to 2100, both in numbers and words (< NUM >), and the list of associated ordinals (< ORD >).2. The names of days (< TAG >), months (< MON >), seasons (< SEAS >).3. The names of the day parts, such as Sabah ("morning"), aks ("evening") etc. (< D-PART >).4. The names of time units, such as saat ("hour"), gu "n (" day "), etc. (< T-UNIT >).5. The modifiers of temporal expressions, such as Deigelecek > (DEwS), etc.

sections.heading: 2.2. Date Expressions
sections.text: Prior to the presentation of the actual Date Entry Patterns (< DATE-EXPR > > > > > Auxiliary Construction Patterns of < DAY-EXPR >, < MON-EXPR >, and < YEAR-EXPR >, which in turn are used within the < DATE-EXPR > Patterns are presented as regular expressions where? null or one-one entries are specified that denote the OR operator and brackets for group purposes. Patterns may include both the classes of lexical entries described in the previous section, and rarely individual entries themselves, such as yıl ("year"), ay ("month"), gu n ("day"), and the saints ("hour").Although they are not denounced in the patterns, there are limitations on lexical entries.

sections.heading: 2.3. Time Expressions
sections.text: The following are the patterns for the usual time expressions in Turkish, and examples corresponding to these patterns are in Table 2. As the final pattern indicates, some time patterns also use extracted date expressions and may be recursive. < TIME-EXPR > < D-PART >? seed? (< NUM >. < NUM >: < NUM >) (8) < TIME-EXPR > < D-PART >? seed < NUM > (9) < TIME-EXPR > < < D-PART > < DAY >? < D-PART > (11) < SUF > * (10) < TIME-EXPR > < TIME-EXPR > < DAY >? < D-PART > < SUDIF > (11) < &ltE-EXPR (EXPR)

sections.heading: 2.4. Set Expressions
sections.text: Below are common patterns for extracting quantity expressions and pattern expressions that match these patterns. < SET-EXPR > < DET > (< T-UNIT > | < TAG > | < MON > | < SEAS >) (13) < SET-EXPR > < T-UNIT > < SUF > < NUM > < QUANT >? (14) < SET-EXPR > < DET >? < NUM >? < T-UNIT > < SUF > < NUM > < QUANT >? (15)

sections.heading: 2.5. Duration Expressions
sections.text: The two patterns for the extraction of permanent expressions in Turkish are listed below and three related examples are shown in Table 4. < DURATION-EXPR > > < NUM > < T-UNIT > (16) < DURATION-EXPR > > < T-UNIT > < SUF > * (17)

sections.heading: 3. Open Issues
sections.text: The open questions on the time extraction of expressions from Turkish texts include the following: • The development of time extraction and normalization systems is an important open question for Turkish. • A convenient system can be achieved by (i) building a rules-based / learning system from scratch, or by (ii) extending an existing Turkish NER system that recognizes date and time expressions, such as (Ku ¼ g and Gertz, 2010) or SUTime (Chang and Manning, 2013) to make it a full-fledged time expression extractor, or (ii) extending an existing Turkish NER system that recognizes date and time expressions, such as (Ku ¼ c, u ¼ k and Yazıcı, 2009) to make it a full-fledged time expression extractor.

sections.heading: 4. Conclusion
sections.text: Extracting temporal expressions is an important task for extracting information, and the corresponding extraction tools make a significant contribution to larger tasks of processing natural language. In this paper, we present a TimeML-based analysis of temporal expressions in Turkish, as related studies to Turkish texts are quite rare. We first describe a temporal lexicon and then use the classes in the lexicon as building blocks to develop a total of 17 comprehensive patterns for extracting date, time, sentence and duration expressions in Turkish.

There are several temporal expression extraction and normalization systems, as reported in studies like (UzZaman et al., 2013).

One of the initial such systems is called GUTime which is the temporal expression recognition and normalization module of a larger system called TARSQI which annotates temporal expressions, relations, and events in news texts (Verhagen et al., 2005).

Several of the system proposals so far, including Edinburgh-LTG (Grover et al., 2010), HeidelTime (Strötgen and Gertz, 2010), SUTime (Chang and Manning, 2013), and FSS-TimEx (Zavarella and Tanev, 2013) are rule-based systems and some of them, such as HeidelTime, have been extended to extract temporal expressions in other languages including Arabic, Italian, Spanish, and Vietnamese (Strötgen et al.

Considering the related tools on Turkish, extraction of date and time expressions has been performed by the rule-based NER system (Küçük and Yazıcı, 2009) and its extended versions like (Küçük and Yazıcı, 2012), mostly following the named entity definition of the MUC series and extracting some deictic date expressions as well, without normalization.

Within a text-based semantic video annotation system, which makes use of this NER system, a separate date normalization module has been implemented to normalize only the deictic date expressions using the creation dates of the corresponding videos as reference dates (Küçük and Yazıcı, 2011).
These writing rules are provided below, following the corresponding language rules published by Türk Dil Kurumu (‘Turkish Language Association’) (TDK, 2015):

A convenient system can be achieved by (i) building a rule-based/learning system from scratch, or by (ii) extending an already existing and open-source temporal expression extractor, like HeidelTime (Strötgen and Gertz, 2010) or SUTime (Chang and Manning, 2013), to Turkish, or by (iii) extending an already existing Turkish NER system recognizing date and time expressions, like (Küçük and Yazıcı, 2009), to make it a full-fledged temporal expression extractor.

A convenient system can be achieved by (i) building a rule-based/learning system from scratch, or by (ii) extending an already existing and open-source temporal expression extractor, like HeidelTime (Strötgen and Gertz, 2010) or SUTime (Chang and Manning, 2013), to Turkish, or by (iii) extending an already existing Turkish NER system recognizing date and time expressions, like (Küçük and Yazıcı, 2009), to make it a full-fledged temporal expression extractor.

The only study that describes a publicly-available Turkish corpus (of tweets) annotated with the MUC-style basic named entity types (person, location, and organization names, money and percentage expressions, along with date and time expressions) is presented in (Küçük et al., 2014).

metadata.abstractText: It is commonly acknowledged that temporal expression extractors are important components of larger natural language processing systems like information retrieval and question answering systems. Extraction and normalization of temporal expressions in Turkish has not been given attention so far except the extraction of some date and time expressions within the course of named entity recognition. We have created a lexicon for Turkish temporal expressions and devised considerably wide-coverage patterns using the lexical classes as the building blocks. We believe that the proposed patterns, together with convenient normalization rules, can be readily used by prospective temporal expression extraction tools for Turkish.
